info.name: library-go-gin-api
info.description:
## **How to use this collection**

#### **Step 1: Send requests**

RESTful APIs allow you to perform CRUD operations such as POST, GET, PUT, or DELETE HTTP methods.

Open each request and click "Send" to see the result.

#### **Step 2: View responses**

Observe the response tab for status code (200 OK), response time, and size.

#### **Step 3: Send new Body data**

Update or add new data in "Body" in the POST request. Typically, Body data is also used in PUT request.

Here's an example for the \[Post new book\] POST request:

``` json
{
    "id": "2",
    "title": "Postman book",
    "author": "Postman author",
    "price": 92.99
}

 ```

#### **Step 4: Update the variable**

Variables enable you to store and reuse values in Postman. This collection has a [variable](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/variables/) called `base_url` pointin to `http://localhost:8080`. You are free to replace it both here and within the API endpoint to customize this repository.

request.description:
This is a GET request and it is used to "get" data from an endpoint. There is no request body for a GET request, but you can use query parameters to help specify the resource you want data on (e.g., in this request, we have `id=1`).

A successful GET response will have a `200 OK` status, and should include some kind of response body - for example, HTML web content or JSON data.

This is a GET request and it is used to "get" data from an endpoint. There is no request body for a GET request, but you can use query parameters to help specify the resource you want data on (e.g., in this request, we have `id=1`).

A successful GET response will have a `200 OK` status, and should include some kind of response body - for example, HTML web content or JSON data.

This is a POST request, submitting data to an API via the request body. This request submits JSON data, and the data is reflected in the response.

A successful POST request typically returns a `200 OK` or `201 Created` response code.

A successful GET response will have a `200 OK` status, and should include some kind of response body - for example, HTML web content or JSON data.

This is a POST request, submitting data to an API via the request body. This request submits JSON data, and the data is reflected in the response.

A successful POST request typically returns a `200 OK` or `201 Created` response code.
